sen.j: 羽二重（はぶたえ、英：habutae silk）は、平織りと呼ばれる経糸（たていと）と緯糸（よこいと）を交互に交差させる織り方で織られた織物の一種。
sen.e: "Habutae" (habutae silk in English) is a kind of plain woven cloth with warp and weft yarns alternately interwoven.

sen.j: 絹を用いた場合は光絹（こうきぬ）とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: When the material is silk, it is called Kokinu.

sen.j: 通常の平織りが緯糸と同じ太さの経糸1本で織るのに対し、羽二重は経糸を細い2本にして織るため、やわらかく軽く光沢のある布となる。
sen.e: While an ordinary plain weave uses warp and weft yarns of the same thickness, habutae is woven using two thinner warp yarns for each one weft yarn so that its texture becomes soft, light and with silky glaze.

sen.j: 白く風合いがとてもよいことから、和服の裏地として最高級であり、礼装にも用いられる。
sen.e: Because of its whiteness with more than good feeling, habutae is used as the highest class liners for wafuku (Japanese kimono garment) and even as the fabric for formal dresses.

sen.j: 日本を代表する絹織物であり『絹のよさは羽二重に始まり羽二重に終わる』といわれる。
sen.e: Habutae represents all Japanese silk fabrics, as being said "the taste of silk fabric begins with habutae and ends with it."

sen.e: Habutae is a traditional Japanese woven cloth, which is said to have originated in the early-modern times.

sen.e: From around 1877, research to improve looms was promoted in Kyoto and Kiryu City in Gunma Prefecture.
